section_content.en: Colombia mapper

short_title.en: Ability of the land to moderate surface water runoff

section_title.en: Ability of the land to moderate surface water runoff

section_content.en: Ecosystem service: Regulation and overland flow
The darkest colours represent where the land makes the greatest contribution to slowing over-land water flow after heavy rainfall events. This helps prevent flooding.

Vegetation can help water soak into the ground and can also form a barrier to water moving rapidly over the land surface. This helps reduce the amount of surface water that can cause flooding. Flat land holds water whilst steep slopes shed water. Some types of soil can hold a lot of water, particularly in wetlands, whilst others hold very little, so soil and geology are important influencing factors.

Surface water regulation is a form of natural flood management where hydrological and morphological processes together with the habitat features work together to manage the sources and pathways for flood waters.

This map was generated by assessing key factors at each location: geology, soil, slope, habitat and management. Datasets representing each key factor were scored based on their functional contribution to mechanisms for natural regulation of overland flow: infiltration; interception; storage and sediment load control. Once scored, the datasets were combined. The current map has been created at the strategic scale and is indicative at a field level. Field visits should be made before any site-specific management decisions are taken. Additional data could be sourced to refine the maps at the local scale; methods for doing this are discussed in the project report.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019). Soil data: Geographic Institute Agustin Codazzi

short_title.en: Opportunities to enhance surface water regulation in the Rio Frio catchment
short_title.es: Oportunidades para mejorar la regulación de las aguas superficiales en la zona de captación del Río Frío

section_title.en: Opportunities to enhance surface water regulation in the Rio Frio catchment

section_content.en: Ecosystem service: Regulation of overland flow.

This map shows places with agriculture and grassland habitat where it would be possible to improve surface water regulation to slow the flow of runoff into the river Frio. Places with the highest number of contributing sub-basins are shown in orange; these form the major flow paths to rivers and channels in the catchment. Areas in purple have fewer contributing sub-basins, and therefore form more minor flow paths to the river and channels. Shading represents where the basins are located in the catchment; lighter shaded basins are higher in the catchment and darker shaded basins are lower in the catchment. All of the coloured areas on the map are hydrologically connected, but management intervention to improve surface water regulation in the valley bottom will be most effective if located along a major flow path (all orange areas).

Generally, interventions in the mid- and upper- reaches of the catchment (pale orange) will benefit a larger downstream area, but can be more challenging to implement, e.g. due to topography and accessibility. In the lower reaches of the catchment the effects of management intervention become more localised (as there is less downstream area), but the benefits can be maximised by targeting areas within major flow paths.

This map was created by analysing the restoration potential of habitat and land use classes generated using Landsat, Sentinel 1 and Sentinel 2 satellite imagery. This was combined with an analysis of SRTM elevation data to derive hydrological basins and sub-basins.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019)

short_title.en: Opportunities to enhance surface water regulation in the Rio Frio catchment: places bordering major drainage channels
short_title.es: Oportunidades para mejorar la regulación de las aguas superficiales en la zona de captación del Río Frío: sitios limítrofes de los principales canales de drenaje

section_title.en: Opportunities to enhance surface water regulation in the Rio Frio catchment: places bordering major drainage channels

section_content.en: Ecosystem service: Regulation of overland flow.

This map shows places that are currently agriculture or grassland, where taking action to improve surface water regulation to slow the flow of runoff into the river Frio, would be most effective. Dark brown places are within sub-basins that directly adjoin a major river, tributary or channel; action should be most effective here. Lighter orange places are also within major flow paths, but do not directly adjoin a major channel.

Water regulation is a form of Natural Flood Management where hydrological and morphological processes, and the type of vegetation present, work together to manage the sources and pathways for flood waters.

Generally, interventions higher up the catchment should benefit a larger area downstream. However, interventions in the mid- and upper reaches of the catchment can be more challenging to implement (e.g. due to topography and accessibility). In the lower reaches of the catchment the effects of management intervention can become more localised (as there is less downstream area). In all parts of the catchment the benefits of action can be maximised by targeting areas closest to the major flow paths (shown in brown)

This map was created by analysing the restoration potential of habitat and land use classes generated using Landsat, Sentinel 1 and Sentinel 2 satellite imagery. This was combined with an analysis of SRTM elevation data to derive hydrological basins and sub-basins.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019)

short_title.en: Risk of soil erosion in the Sierra Nevada caused by precipitation
short_title.es: Riesgo de erosión del suelo en la Sierra Nevada causado por lluvias

section_title.en: Risk of soil erosion in the Sierra Nevada caused by precipitation

section_content.en: Ecosystem services: Conservation of soil and water quality. Limiting sediment entering rivers
Places of highest risk are coloured red. Areas of lower risk are coloured blue.

Land erosion risk is a significant factor leading to loss of soil, soil quality degradation, siltation of rivers, damage to habitats and wildlife, and damage to buildings, roads, and other infrastructure.

Soil is a non-renewable resource and where it is lost through erosion, it can take hundreds to thousands of years to re-form. Losing soil disrupts the physical structure of the soil and the balance of biological communities which regulate soil functions, degrading soil quality. Nutrients and chemicals in the soil can be detrimental to the freshwater, wetland and marine habitats they reach, as well as the associated wildlife.

This map was created using SCIMAP which is a framework for modelling and mapping diffuse pollution risk across landscapes. It considers slope, habitats and average precipitation. The map has been created using SRTM, WorldClim, Landsat, Sentinel 1 and Sentinel 2 data. The current map has been created at the strategic scale and is indicative at a field level. Field visits should be undertaken before any site-specific management decisions are taken. Additional data could be sourced to refine the maps at the local scale; methods for doing this are discussed in the project report.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019) SCIMAP by Sim Reaney, Durham University is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License

short_title.en: Risk of soil erosion caused by wind
short_title.es: Riesgo de erosión del suelo causado por el viento

section_title.en: Risk of soil erosion caused by wind

section_content.en: Ecosystem services: Conservation of soil and water quality. Limiting sediment entering rivers.
Orange colours are places where soils are likely to be more susceptible to wind erosion, with dark orange places being most susceptible.

Topsoil erosion risk is a significant factor leading to loss of soil, soil quality degradation, reduction in agricultural productivity, and siltation of rivers and streams. Some soil types are more susceptible to wind erosion due to their texture, stoniness and organic matter content.

Soil is a non-renewable resource and where it is lost through erosion, it can take hundreds to thousands of years to re-form. Losing topsoil removes a nutrient rich growing-medium for plants, and also reduces the water infiltration capacity of the soil, leading to increased runoff. Land use management can have a large influence on wind erosion, particularly if dry, susceptible soils are exposed when erosive winds are likely to occur.

This map is based on an analysis of soil characteristics as mapped within the Digital Soil Map of the Department of Magdalena, Republic of Colombia. Scale 1: 100,000 (2009). Soil classes and their relative abundances were assessed for their susceptibility to wind erosion, so that soils with the highest risk and which are present in over 60% of an area, are given the highest risk. Areas where the same soil type is present, but in lower proportions, are assessed as lower risk.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019). Soil data: Geographic Institute Agustín Codazzi

short_title.en: Places with habitat of key importance for biodiversity
short_title.es: Sitios con hábitat de importancia clave para la biodiversidad

section_title.en: Places with habitat of key importance for biodiversity

section_content.en: Ecosystem services: Population maintenance & genetic diversity

The map shows existing areas of natural or semi-natural grassland, wetland or woodland that are important for supporting biological and genetic diversity. Areas of disturbed woodland are not included as they are likely to be less diverse than undisturbed woodland.

The map shows areas of natural or semi-natural vegetation, that are likely to support populations of a wide range of species, and high overall biodiversity. Biodiversity is a supporting service which underpins many other ecosystem services such as soil quality, pollination, food provision and surface water regulation.

These habitats are core components of the ecological networks, which facilitate gene flow between species populations and increase ecological resilience, and have an impact on related ecosystem services, such as the ability of land to regulate surface water runoff, and habitat for pollinators.

The habitat classes were generated using Landsat, Sentinel 1 and Sentinel 2 satellite imagery. The map has been created at the strategic scale and is indicative at a field level. Field visits should be undertaken before any specific management decisions are taken.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019)

short_title.en: Places delivering multiple ecosystem service benefits: key areas for biodiversity and surface water regulation
short_title.es: Sitios que ofrecen múltiples beneficios de servicios ecosistémicos: áreas clave para la biodiversidad y la regulación de aguas superficiales

section_title.en: Places delivering multiple ecosystem service benefits: key areas for biodiversity and surface water regulation

section_content.en: Ecosystem services: Population maintenance & genetic diversity. Regulation of overland flow
The map identifies areas of source habitat (grassland, woodland, wetland) which coincide with areas providing high surface water regulation.

Source habitats function as the core of the ecological networks. The structure and naturalness of the vegetation in these areas provides high biodiversity value. These vegetation characteristics combine with characteristics of the soil, geology and slope and together they provide high levels of surface water. Biodiversity is a supporting service which underpins many other ecosystem services such as soil quality, pollination and food provision. Surface water regulation is a form of natural flood management, where hydrological and morphological processes, together with the habitat features, work together to manage the sources and pathways for flood waters.

Surface water regulation and biodiversity are important ecosystem services in their own right. However, identifying places which provide high levels of multiple ecosystem services could be considered more valuable than those providing a single ecosystem service. The protection of places of high biodiversity value that also provide high levels of natural flood management is likely to be a good investment.

This map is derived from two other ecosystem service maps in this series: “Ability of the land to moderate surface water runoff” (Map 1; areas with highest levels of provision) and “Places with habitat of high importance for biodiversity” (Map 2).

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019)

short_title.es: Conectividad de red ecológica – Ecosistema forestal

section_content.en: Ecosystem service: Population maintenance & genetic diversity
Dark green areas are more highly connected to the ecological network. Grey areas are existing source woodlands (excludes disturbed woodlands).

The map shoes the existing woodland network within which plant and animal species can move to maintain genetic diversity and sustain viable populations of woodland species. Existing woodlands at as ‘source habitat’, where the main population of woodland species is based. Land adjoining and close to the source habitats can be used for foraging and as dispersal routes (permeable habitats). Some habitats and land uses are more permeable than others; for example, scrub could be expected to provide greater levels of food and shelter for woodland species, whereas bare ground would provide less.

Areas of native natural and semi-natural woodlands that are connected in a landscape, forming a network, are more resilient to changing climate or land management. Inside the network woodlands generally provide a higher level of ecosystem services, such as the ability to clean water or regulate runoff, provide timber products and support nature tourism (e.g. bird watching). Within the network restoration of structurally-diverse and species-rich woodlands will be far more effective as propagules, pollinators and important species will be available for colonisation.

The habitat classes were generated using the freely available Landsat, Sentinel 1 and Sentinel 2 satellite imagery. Each habitat and land use was evaluated for its importance and role played in the woodland ecosystem.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019)

short_title.es: Conectividad de red ecológica – Ecosistema de humedales

section_content.en: Ecosystem services: Lifecycle maintenance & genetic diversity
Darker blue areas are more highly connected to the ecological network. Black (Grey) areas are existing source wetlands (excludes artificial wetlands).

The map shows the existing wetland network within which plant and animal species can move to maintain genetic diversity and sustain viable populations of wetland species. Existing wetlands act as ‘source habitat’, where the main population of wetland species is based. Land adjoining and close to the source habitats can be used for foraging and as dispersal routes (permeable habitats). Some habitats are land uses are more permeable than others; for example rivers could be expected to provide suitable conditions for many wetland species, whereas terrestrial habitats are less suitable.

Areas of native natural and semi-natural wetlands that are joined together in a landscape, forming a network, are more resilient to changing climate or land management. Inside the network, wetlands with low chemical and nutrient levels and structurally-diverse and species-rich emergent vegetation generally provide a higher level of ecosystem services, such as clean freshwaters, erosion control, and nursery fisheries. Within the network restoration of structurally-diverse and species-rich emergent vegetation will be far more effective as propagules, pollinators and important species will be available for colonisation.

The habitat classes were generated using the freely available Landsat, Sentinel 1 and Sentinel 2 satellite imagery. Each habitat and land use was evaluated for its importance and role played in the wetland ecosystem.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019)

short_title.es: Conectividad de red ecológica – Ecosistema de pastizales

section_content.en: Ecosystem services: Population maintenance & genetic diversity
Darker orange areas are more highly connected to the ecological network. Grey (Black) areas are existing source grasslands.

The map shows the existing grassland network within which plant and animal species can move to maintain genetic diversity and sustain viable populations of grassland species. Existing grasslands act as ‘source habitat’, where the main population of grassland species is based. Land adjoining and close to the source habitats can be used for foraging and as dispersal routes (permeable habitat). Some habitats and land uses are more permeable than others; for example scattered scrub could be expected to provide better conditions for grassland species than dense woodland.

Areas of native natural and semi-natural grasslands that are connected in a landscape, forming a network, are more resilient to changing climate or land management. Inside the network, structurally diverse and species-rich grassland swards generally provide a higher level of ecosystem services, such as surface water regulation. Within the network restoration of structurally-diverse and species-rich grasslands will be far more effective as propagules, pollinators and important species will be available for colonisation.

The habitat classes were generated using the freely available Landsat, Sentinel 1 and Sentinel 2 satellite imagery. Each habitat and land use was evaluated for its importance and role played in the grassland network.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019)

short_title.es: Oportunidades para fortalecer las redes ecológicas

section_content.en: Ecosystem service: Lifecycle maintenance & genetic diversity

The map shows places where it would be possible to restore or create new habitat to strengthen the existing grassland, wetland or woodland networks, to enhance biological and genetic biodiversity. Places in darker shades are areas where habitat restoration/creation are expected to be most easily implemented and more successful. For example, developing a woodland from an area of dense scrub or bare ground may be a suitable choice in both places, but is quicker, less labour intensive and less costly from the dense scrub vegetation.
Biodiversity is a supporting service which underpins many other ecosystem services.

This map considered all areas in close proximity to existing source habitat; areas more distant to the source habitats; these areas are most likely to be effective at supporting existing populations. Habitats and land use within this proximity zone were assessed as to the ease at which they could be restored to support the ecological networks. Where restoration to woodland was possible, this option was always chosen. In other places, where restoration to either grassland or wetland is possible, this is indicated.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd

short_title.en: Opportunities to strengthen ecological networks: priority places for action (those adjoining existing key habitats of highbiodiversity value)
short_title.es: Oportunidades para fortalecer las redes ecológicas: lugares prioritarios para tomar acción (sitios adyacentes a hábitats clave existentes de alto valor de biodiversidad)

section_title.en: Opportunities to strengthen ecological networks: priority places for action (those adjoining existing key habitats of high-biodiversity value)

section_content.en: Ecosystem service: Population maintenance & genetic diversity

The map is a subset of Map 11 and shows only those places that adjoin existing source habitat, where habitat restoration is likely to be most successful and beneficial to existing habitat of key biodiversity value. Areas next to existing biodiversity hotspots are likely to provide most benefit to existing species populations, allowing the expansion of local native species via dispersal or territory expansion. Restoration of structurally-diverse and species-rich habitat will be far more effective close to the source habitats, as propagules, pollinators and important species will be available for colonisation.
Biodiversity is a supporting service which underpins many other ecosystem services such as soil quality, pollination and food provision.

This map considered places immediately adjoining existing source habitat, as defined by the ecological network maps in this series. Habitats and land uses next to the source habitats were assessed as to the ease at which they could be restored to support the grassland, wetland or woodland network.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019)

short_title.en: Opportunities to deliver multiple ecosystem services: ecological connectivity and surface water regulation
short_title.es: Oportunidades para generar múltiples servicios ecosistémicos: conectividad ecológica y regulación de las aguas superficiales

section_title.en: Opportunities to deliver multiple ecosystem services: ecological connectivity and surface water regulation

section_content.en: Ecosystem services: Regulation of overland flow. Population maintenance & genetic diversity.

The map shows places where it should be possible to restore or create new habitat to strengthen the existing grassland, wetland or woodland ecological networks to enhance biodiversity, while simultaneously enhancing the level of surface water regulation.

Biodiversity is a supporting service which underpins many other ecosystem services such as soil quality, pollination and food provision. Surface water regulation in a form of natural flood management, which manages the sources and pathways for flood waters.

Surface water regulation and biodiversity are important ecosystem services in their own right. However, identifying places which provide high levels of multiple ecosystem services can help to inform the decision-making process when prioritising areas for land management action, in order to provide the best value for money.

This map is derived by combining information for two other ecosystem service maps in this series: ‘Opportunities to enhance surface water regulation in the Rio Frio catchment (Map 9) and ‘Opportunities to strengthen ecological networks (Map 11)’. It identifies places that could be restored to support the ecological networks, and which currently provide relatively low surface water regulation.

attribution.en: Data and maps created by Environment Systems Ltd (2019). Soil data: Geographic institute Agustin Codazzi
